poem:
"Echoes of November"

Not Ishmael, I,
in graying of grim November,
a pauper's purse, heart heavy,
drawn to water's edge.

Limestone giants lay idle,
playground of Titans past,
pebbles whispering secrets
in infinite echo.

I, south-west bound,
chasing melancholy mists,
with only November's song
and giants for companionship.
prompt: You are the poet Carol Ann Duffy. You woke up this morning feeling nostalgic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: A giant’s playground of limestone blocks and infinite pebbles | Anita Roy My name is not Ishmael, but like the narrator of Moby-Dick, sometimes I have the urge – with little or no money in my purse – to see the watery part of the world. November is a damp and drizzly month in the soul for Ishmael, and I too have grown a bit grim about the mouth, so I head south-west to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
